title: “Quarto Basics” format: html: code-fold: true jupyter: python3 —
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis

title: Irving Martínez Acosta
text:
About
I am a mathematical scientist working on applied mathematics, scientific computing, and modeling. My interests include numerical analysis, PDEs, inverse problems, and data‑driven methods.
I focus on bridging mathematical theory with computational practice, with applications in physics and engineering.
